qas.question: Why do miniature PM motors use high energy magnets?

answers.text: To minimize overall weight and size

qas.question: What are high energy magnets typically made of?
What does the outer housing of a miniature motor resemble?
How do PMs rate against other types of electric motors?
Why do large PM motors use high energy magnets?
What are high energy magnets never made of?
What doesn't the outer housing of a miniature motor resemble?
How do PMs rate with other types of electric motors?

context: <a0_0>To <b4_0>minimize overall weight and size<a0_0/>,<b4_0/> miniature PM motors may use high energy magnets made with neodymium or other strategic elements; most such are <a1_0><b5_0>neodymium-iron-boron alloy<b5_0/><a1_0/>. With their higher flux density, electric machines with high-energy PMs are at <a3_0><b7_0>least competitive<b7_0/><a3_0/> with all optimally designed singly-fed synchronous and induction electric machines. Miniature motors resemble the structure in the illustration, except that they have at least three rotor poles (to ensure starting, regardless of rotor position) and their outer housing is a <a2_0><b6_0>steel tube<b6_0/><a2_0/> that magnetically links the exteriors of the curved field magnets.
